Fields.DialogueText: Whoa, Vampire! Slow down!
Ha! You speed up, Captain! We'll train the bludger right out of you!
Well, since you invited me... here I come!
That's the way! Keep up; the crew are watching!

Fields.MenuText: I can barely hear you speak over this wind!
I'll catch you for sure!
Let them see why I'm captain!

Fields.DialogueText: Beauty! That's how you know you're moving!
Not bloody likely! I can run as fast as I can swim!
Keep that pace and I might shorten your usual head start!
And... time! Slow down, everyone. You've earned a walk.
If we're to win the war, we've got to be in top condition.
Assuming we're boarded by the Morganas.
It's been known to happen. But I'm thinking more that what's good for the body is good for the soul.
I think we might have the fittest crew in the fleet.
*ALARM*
Don't forget patience. The Morganas certainly wear on that.
I've always said rest is the most important part of exercise. Got to let those muscles grow back stronger.
@BATTLE
Everyone has them. Sometimes you just have to get out of your own way to see it.
Discipline and confidence are muscles too.
Beautiful evening, isn't it?
Too beautiful to stay dark. Hence the mood lighting.
And I'm sure the fire in that barrel has nothing to do with the night air.
Are you going to come join me where it's warm or are you going to stand there like a tiger cat in headlights?
Would you like my jacket as well?
If you wouldn't mind.

Fields.MenuText: You're going to be in real trouble if the Morganas develop a freeze ray.
You'd think your cloak would help more.
Brr. Now I see what you mean.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, don't be silly. Have you been talking to one of the American girls or something?
So would I! This air just wears every layer down... insidious stuff.
Didn't I tell you? Come on, there's room enough for both of us.
I thought the Philippines might be a little warmer.
The evening breeze can set your teeth right on edge when you least expect it. Maybe I should start training at night to stay warm.
You've been in the North Sea before, haven't you?
That was even worse! I don't know how my sisters could stand it.
Funny.
What's funny?
Valhalla and Valkyrie were named for Norse mythology, weren't they? It's colder up there where those stories come from. Maybe that helped.
The fact that I don't burst into flames during our midday runs should put paid to that theory.
Besides, even the heroes of the myths I love had to earn their strength.
Aren't there a lot of demigods in those stories? Seems an unfair advantage.
Just because I'm a Belle doesn't mean I can't get stronger. And if I don't stay sharp, I can absolutely get weaker.
If you can, I've never seen it happen. I doubt I ever will.
Odin willing.
... You can come a little closer, if you like. It must be chilly over there without your jacket.
*ALARM*
Or don't. Looks like I'm getting that warmup I wished for!
@BATTLE
All ahead full, Vampire. We're cleaning out the Dinagat Sound today.
A right Augean Stables job if ever I heard of one.
Hercules did some farm work in one of the stories. Let's just say it was dirty business.
@BATTLE
This calls for another campfire, I think.
Too right, Captain. I picked up some plantains in port to cook for a nice victory treat.
I've always loved cookouts. Roasting over an open fire... sleeping under the stars... campfire ghost stories...
You had me until that last bit. Leave the stories to sleepaway camp.

Fields.MenuText: I thought you liked mythology.
Oh, come on. It could be fun.
Is Vampire scared of a spooky story or two?

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, come on. All the best myths started out as oral traditions.
Creation stories, Captain. How the world came to be and why it is the way it is. Fate, hope, grief, honor and humanity...
What about that berbalang myth you like so much?
It's probably nothing more than one tribe telling foreign missionaries their neighbours were yobbos. But at least it tells you something about what they as a people feared and how they dealt with it.
Maybe you should share some of those with us, then. Something real.
I'll think about it. But I'll be thinking harder about those plantains.
Oh, believe me, so will I! Maybe there ought to be a proper shipwide barbie.
I'm not sure I get the reference.
There's a difference between time-honored cultural touchstones and ghost stories.
My fears are much more tangible than campfire nasties.
I'll bring the food, but I reserve the right not to participate in some silly Halloween panto.
That's what interests me. Not some silliness about haunted houses.
I'll take you up on that. Bring a plate!
Comfortable up there?
Now shh! I'm getting to a really good part.
*ALARM*
Ooh, something to look forward to. Hah!
Nice dismount. You might have a future as an acrobat after the war.
Ha! When I'm a museum ship, I'll be a library and not a circus. Now let's get those Morganas to be quiet!
@BATTLE
That's that sorted. Now to get back to my book...

Fields.MenuText: I thought you didn't like horror stories.
Hmm... Sounds like something I might like to read.
Isn't that the one about the monster?

Fields.DialogueText: I don't. This happens to be a science fiction story with horror in it.
I'll lend it to you once I'm done. It'll be my third or fourth time reading it anyway.
Was he a monster, Captain? Or was he just a man denied his humanity?
This is a little more recent than what I usually see you reading.
It's got just as much to say about humanity as any myth does. Shelley calls Frankenstein the Modern Prometheus, after all.
Prometheus... that's Greek, right?
Indeed! Ripper story with the same ripper moral. What happens when you create life and abandon it? When it doesn't do what you expect it should?
I can see how a Belle would really take to that kind of story.
This mast is one of my favorite places to hang from. Not a lot of people try to disturb me up here.
What are you reading?
A classic, Captain. Mary Shelley's Frankenstein!
Well, you humans didn't know you were creating life when you built us. I never have to worry about you abandoning me, though.
Of course not. We never leave a fellow sailor behind.
Especially if she can tilt from side to side and make you seasick.
Big incentive.
Something tells me you could take it.
Here you go, Captain! I finally finished my book!
Thanks, Vampire. Any dry parts I should skip over?
Of course not! It's like a mystery bag. Every part of it contributes to the taste.

Fields.MenuText: We'll see if it's my taste.
Thank you, Vampire. I'm excited to catch up to you.
I don't know if a sausage metaphor's the best way to describe a story about a reanimated corpse.

Fields.DialogueText: I think you'll be surprised. The narrator's a captain too!
Think of this as an exercise for the mind!
Maybe not the best, but a real gobsmacker of an image.
You know, I think I've heard about this before. Wasn't this the result of a scary story contest?
Ooh, I was hoping you wouldn't bring that up. Fine, I concede. They have their place if properly crafted.
To pass the time?
Hmm... I'll think on it, Captain. But it can't be about Morganas or sea monsters. People see heaps of those these days.
But we're free to come up with whatever else we want, right?
Then I'm excited! Let's see if these Morganas might give us some inspiration.
@BATTLE
Maybe that's what we should do. You and me each come up with a ghost story.
To make something that gets people talking. That outlives us both.
You'll find me the most honest person aboard this ship.
As long as it's honest. I can tell if something comes from the heart, whether it's scary or happy.
Vampire? I came back to return your book.
Thank you so much! I see it's still in good condition. Did you enjoy it?
Oh, I'm so glad! It's really given me lots to think about.
On the whole, it's interesting. You really feel for the monster.
Was he a monster at all? Maybe monsters are the people their creators have failed.
Whoever they were, Captain, they certainly didn't have as strong a sense of style as we Belles do.
You Belles? Or us humans?
We're getting down a rabbit hole I don't think we've time to explore.
Not really, to be honest.
You might listen to the crew for inspiration. Some of the stories they tell are downright bizarre.
Always trust the sailors to find interesting yarns in port. No matter how preposterous.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: Actually a lot more than I expected to.
It wasn't my thing, but I can see what you'd like about it.
I gave it a try, but I just couldn't finish it.

Fields.DialogueText: No drama, Captain. It starts bleak and goes bleaker. Not for everyone.
There's definitely a right mood for it. The Belle thing helps, too.
I have trouble with that. Doesn't it make you think about the Morganas? Who their creators were?
That reminds me, Captain! Have you thought about what your story's to be about?
Well, keep at it. I don't write as quickly as I run, so you've a fair go at beating me.
*ALARM*
What do they need ghost stories for when they've got real ghost ships to fight?
If you humans are good at one thing, it's adaptation. Even to something truly ratbag.
I... I was watching the seas as usual.
Right. We got that far.
And all of a sudden there was this strange light on the water!

Fields.MenuText: Don't be ridiculous. She's a Belle and you'll treat her as such.
Stay on topic. What else did you see?
Now that he mentions it...

Fields.DialogueText: Besides, even if I were a real vampire, I wouldn't eat any of my crew. Too obvious.
And had you been drinking?
Crikey, has everyone gone batty?
T-that's all. Oh! And it smelled like... burning?
This light... kind of spherical in appearance, yeah?
Ball lightning. Nothing to worry about.
St. Elmo's fire. It's not unheard of at sea.
Looks like we're going to be spilling a little of our own. Dismissed to action stations. Vampire?
On it. Let's hit the frog and toad.
@BATTLE
All right, explain what you saw. Clearly.
Sorry I'm late. Give me the full John Dory.
M-Miss Vampire! Maybe you'd know what's going on.
Is it something to do with the Morganas?
I don't know, but something's definitely odd. I figured you'd have some idea, since you're... you know...
Say it. Out loud.
... You're not a real vampire, are you?
Why don't you field this one, Captain?
Yes, yes it was.
That's what it was! A santilmo. I heard about them in port. Fire spirits that come out where blood is spilled!
*ALARM*
So... Philippine folklore.
Philippine folklore. Let's talk about it.
I'm not one for censorship, but we'll have to pay close attention to the sort of goss flying round the ship.

Fields.MenuText: Feeling a little cornered?
You don't think that might make people suspicious?
We can't control it.

Fields.DialogueText: Rack off. This isn't about me.
If we nip the paranoia in the bud, I'm willing to make that sacrifice.
No, but we can control what people do with it.
I think we're making a little too much out of this.
You never know. Sailors are a superstitious lot.
That's just how people are. They come up with these things to fill in the blanks where they don't have the answers.
There's a difference between the no-bananas rule and pitchforks and torches.
No bananas?
Sailor superstition. Long story.
What the lookout said about santilmos didn't seem too dangerous.
Quite right.
"Where blood is spilled?" Not a long leap, Captain.
I'd have to do some reading, but I know they have vampire equivalents. Aswangs, they call them.
Does this mean no fried plantains?
Absolutely not, Captain. I'll be damned if those are a casualty of this nonsense.
*ALARM*
Speaking of minimising casualties...
Right behind you.
@BATTLE
Heard the latest from the radiomen?
This ought to be good.
So little faith in your crew, Captain?

Fields.MenuText: Maybe I am being a little hard on them. Those shifts can be awfully long and boring.
At this rate I'd rather have you down in the radio room.
When they start thinking they can fight you, I have to wonder.

Fields.DialogueText: Not everyone gets so bored they start seeing ghosts.
We all have to make sacrifices, but it's nice not to have to.
I admire confidence. It's when they start taking on invincible ship spirits that it rates a good drubbing.
I'd wondered why they looked so tired. Hitting the coffee again, are they?
Oh, I wish, Captain. They've been skiving.
Usually they're so dutiful when it comes to getting the better of you.
Trying to get the better of me. They've been doing their jobs, but they've been taking it in shifts to search for one frequency in particular.
I'm afraid to ask.
Some of them think they can find the ghosts our lookout has seen.
Now I've heard everything.
Not everything, Captain. That ghost frequency continues to elude you.
Maybe you should write your story about that.
Oh, come off it. We get enough interference from the Morganas already.
*ALARM*
See?
Maybe that's what's messing with the crew. Their broadcasts can't be healthy to listen to.
As long as I'm around they're protected from the worst of it, but there's a reason they rotate as often as they do.
@BATTLE
Just a friendly jog today, Captain. These recent sessions have been real ripsnorters.
Your idea of a friendly jog is... exhilarating.
Good! You're getting fairly ace at them. A while ago this pace would have left you in the dust.
Maybe we can talk about how our stories are going.

Fields.MenuText: Not even a monster?

Fields.DialogueText: Who said it had to be a monster? There are plenty of bonzer horror stories without.
Well, let's get you going. What's been on your mind lately?
I'd almost forgotten about the cookout.
I hadn't. If there's one thing you needn't fear, it's my cooking. Garlic isn't the only thing I can slow-roast!
I don't know that I'd want to find out. The idea of ghosts always seemed so sad to me.
Unfinished business?
There's a lot of stories in this part of the world about vengeful ghosts. Japan have their onryō. And there's almost as many legends as there are islands here in the Philippines.
You'd have to write a story like that from their perspective. I can't imagine anything scarier than being trapped somehow, unable to change the world around you.
You're right. If I were to write that story, that'd be the way of it. But it isn't my story to tell. It's theirs.
I'm starting to see why you don't like ghost stories.
Not much to big-note about, I'm afraid. I haven't really decided on a plot.

Fields.MenuText: Neither have I, to tell you the truth.
I knew I'd get ahead of you on something.

Fields.DialogueText: London to a brick we'll think of something, Captain. I've heard these things sneak up on you when you least expect it.
Well done! You're a real conch, Captain. Just keep at it - I'll catch up the second you take a smoko.
Oh, the usual. Our barbie. The war. My sisters.
That's something to look forward to. All right, ghost stories. The war doesn't scare you. That leaves... your sisters? Do Belles have ghosts?
I never saw Valhalla and Valkyrie awake, Captain. But they weren't the type to go to their graves as quietly as they did.
If they were ghosts, they'd either be very angry or very sad. So for their sake... I hope they're gone for good.
Didn't mean to crack a sad there, Captain. Just where my head's at. I'll find a way around this.
*ALARM*
That way might be through some Morganas.
Let's finish their business, then!
@BATTLE
Stations, everyone. Another round with the Morganas!
Getting any ideas for your story, Captain?
Would I spoil the surprise for you?
@BATTLE
I'm getting right stuffed of these girls.

Fields.MenuText: Belle parties must be something else.
You'll all rent out the Isle of Wight when this is over.
What would Valhalla and Valkyrie be like?

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, they're dinkum ragers, Captain! It doesn't really get started until the first shooting contest... or duel.
Ooh, we'd be going off for days. A family reunion and a victory celebration in one is not to be taken lightly!
Much like the Greek girls in the Fleet, I expect. Perth and Orion are the closest in terms of personality. They love them a good skull.
I imagine humans must party a little less hard than you'd like.
Depends on the Belle, and on the human. You have a way of surprising us, even though we should know you best.
We built you, after all.
And a corker of a job you did with us!
It seems the best compliments benefit the giver and the receiver.
Because they tell you something about the relationship between the two. That makes it more interesting than a simple "love your hair."
I do, incidentally.
Fair's fair. I'll think of more.
If you'd come up with one to spoil by now, I'm sure I could weasel it out of you.
Well sleuthed. Maybe you should be writing a mystery story.
I wish I could tell you there's an end in sight.
Times like these I wish my sisters were all around to unwind with.
Oh, you saucy plagiarist. I just said that.
What do they report?
The usual madness about groaning sounds and cold spots. It's all a lot of Flemington confetti if you ask me.

Fields.MenuText: Groans and chills, eh? Sounds like your structure could use some work.

Fields.DialogueText: Don't be vile. They're just passing the time in the least useful possible way.
Nobody's... died aboard you, have they?
Even if they had, Captain, why wait until now to spook us?
Unfinished business? Maybe one of the sailors is related to someone who died.
We've rotated and recrewed since the war began. It's not bloody likely.
Hmm. Well, the sea's full of sunken ships and lost crew. Maybe we sailed over a ship graveyard.
Have you any idea how many people have died at sea? All the ships would be floating spooky share houses.
We've got to figure something out. I keep seeing people look over their shoulders like something's tailing them. It's only a matter of time before someone drops something heavy.
Hmm... Stand watch with me next time, Captain.
You think we'll see a ghost?
I think we'll see what people think is a ghost. Besides, I like the night shifts better when you're around. It's-
*ALARM*
Bugger everything. Action stations!
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: It'll blow over. You said before we adapt to all kinds of things.
Should I talk to the crew?

Fields.DialogueText: Where it gets dangerous is when some drongo decides to do something about it.
I'd hold off. Denials on their own have a way of stoking the very fire you're trying to snuff.
Your exercise sessions have been really well attended lately.
I'm glad they're taking it so seriously. Though what some extra muscle they think might do to a ghost, I can't begin to fathom.
This has to be the silliest idea I've ever had.
Just one night of ghost hunting, Vampire. Then we can tell the crew to see sense and get on with our lives.
Is that-
Oi! Sailor!
Didn't you just tell me to be quiet?
Explain yourself. And that butterfly net.
Traded for it in port. It's consecrated.
I didn't realise the Catholic Church were in entomology.

Fields.MenuText: What would you do with one if you caught it?
Whatever you're doing, cut it out. We're in contested waters.
What did you trade for it?

Fields.DialogueText: I figured I'd know when I got that far.
This could be a contested ship!
Last of my grog ration. I've got to be stone cold sober for a ghost hunt.
Well, the Belle and I are on the case. You can get below decks and rethink your hobbies.
*FOOTSTEPS*
You were saying?
Wait! Quiet, Captain. Do you see that?
Gah!
Oh, for the love of... Take off the sheets! Right now!
I told you this was a stupid idea.
And I told you we should have dyed these sheets black!
Did you start this whole ghost nonsense or did you decide it looked like fun?
*ALARM*
Never mind. We'll forget the whole thing if you do. Just get to your stations.
@BATTLE
Ockers baiting ockers. I'm more mad at myself for chasing the nothing.
Don't beat yourself up. We did well to crack down before the crew started something they couldn't stop.
Clearly I'm not running them hard enough. I'll give them something to spend their time on.
I'll say this. It's given me plenty of time to come up with story ideas.
Oh, me too, Captain. What's rattling around your mind?

Fields.MenuText: I was thinking about a vampire story. About the last human on the planet.

Fields.DialogueText: Bit of stiff cheese for him, isn't it? I'd ask to join up in his situation. Not that I'm biased.
All right, then, where are you in the creative proc-
Wasn't me, Captain. Belles can stabilise to mitigate the motion of the ocean. Well, I do. Common courtesy.
Something had to have knocked it over.
It's not a lot of effort on my part, but when the seas get choppy-
Focus. We-
*ALARM*
Damn it. This is going to haunt me for the whole battle...
@BATTLE
So the haunting really was a load of nothing.

Fields.MenuText: Some down-on-their-luck ghost hunters in the big city.
I like the idea of a killer that makes his victims escape deadly traps.

Fields.DialogueText: Sounds more like a comedy than a horror.
That's a bit morbid even for me. Where's the point in suffering?
*THUD*
Did you make that bookshelf-
Honestly, Captain, you're starting to sound like the crew.
Maybe I am. It doesn't change the fact that three separate sailors reported disturbances in their furniture.

Fields.MenuText: This isn't just an isolated incident.

Fields.DialogueText: It could be four isolated incidents. There's a rational explanation staring us in the face.
I wasn't commissioned to look for monsters under the bed, Captain!
And yet that's exactly what we did, in the name of keeping people from making their own.
I brought this on myself, didn't I?
I helped.

Fields.MenuText: I'm not bringing the whole crew to a halt over this. We can get to the bottom of it.

Fields.DialogueText: All right. As long as you keep helping. I'm not sifting through this nonsense without someone to split the wine with at the end of the day.
We got to the bottom of it when we set the bookshelf right.
So what do we do now?
*ALARM*
Something tangible. We can figure this out once we have time to waste.
@BATTLE
If we split the dummy every time someone's things get knocked over, the Morganas will catch us napping for sure.

Fields.MenuText: You can't say this doesn't at least inspire you.

Fields.DialogueText: I most certainly can! Whatever I write is going to blow this nonsense right out of the water.
Time for a few exorcisms.
What's that smell?
Did I get too much incense?
Maybe. I can barely see you.
If some is good, more is better, isn't it? Besides, if we're doing something mad I'd rather it smell like sage.

Fields.MenuText: You're mocking this whole thing, aren't you?
Last I checked, smoke was still smoke.
Why here?

Fields.DialogueText: I can do more than one thing at a time.
Good thing everything I need to do my job is right here in front of me.
If anyone can control what happens aboard me, it's me. Ghosts don't like change. They'll complain to me first.
If only the radio crew were here to see this.
I gave them the day off. Thought I'd put them where they could do the least damage, considering their pet subject has flared up once more.
If it meant not having to sit in an enclosed, smoke-filled room, I'd jump at the offer.
I'm regretting my selflessness already. Wait! Hang on a tick...
What is it?
I tuned it to their ghost frequency for a lark. There's heaps of interference... unless...
*khzz* ... TRY AGAIN... *khzz*
Shall we ventilate a bit?
Righto. But for the sake of exhausting all our options, I'm at least defending this one.
Wait... hear that?
Morganas. I've been switching back to their frequency periodically.
@BATTLE
Looks like our poltergeist wasn't impressed.
Not a word of this to the radiomen, Captain. They'd be laughing for the rest of the tour.
Let's get to stations, then.
Watch your ten o'clock, Captain.
Whoa!
Nice catch. I'd hate to see that teacup go.
Are we going to continue ignoring the incorporeal elephant in the room?
Shh! It wants attention. If we stop giving it what it wants, it might leave.

Fields.MenuText: Or it might get bored and start sabotaging your machinery.
Something tells me it's got all the time in the world.
Do we even know that's all it wants?

Fields.DialogueText: And put itself out of a home? It's dead, not stupid.
Even spirits can get bored. I think.
What reason have we got to believe otherwise?
I kind of feel sorry for it.
I was afraid you'd say that.
Afraid you'd agree with me.
I knew I'd agree with you. I suppose I was just being stubborn.
So the crew were right about something silly. If it's as easy as listening to a ghost, I'm willing to hear it out.
Too right, Captain. One condition.
Name it.
I get to use this as inspiration for my story.
But-
Too late. Called it.
I think I get a say in this.
*ALARM*
You mean all this time you still hadn't come up with a plot?
No. I mean...
Action stations?
That.
@BATTLE
Where did we get this spirit board?
Our lookout found it in port. The seller seemed quite glad to be rid of it. Suppose that's why it was such a bottler of a deal.
So how does this work?
We rest our hands on the planchette like this and ask a question. Then our friend moves it.
Right, then.

Fields.MenuText: What do you want?
Who are you?
Will I win the ghost story contest?

Fields.DialogueText: Straight to the point. Good on you.
I wonder how long it's been since it was asked that.
Where's your sense of sportsmanship?
Now we wait.
Don't rush the dead. They don't perceive time the way we-
*ALARM*
It was a fair go.
@BATTLE
And wait.
Come on. It'll be here when we get back.
You were saying?
How the hell - no, why the hell would this thing be glued to the ceiling?
It seems our poltergeist has a sense of humour.
Do we even bother taking it down? I feel silly just acknowledging it.
We have to draw the line somewhere, Captain. It worked on the crew.
Our crew aren't spirits with all the time in the world.
I am. Good thing you've got me by your side.
On my side.
That's what I said.
That too.
Captain... can we talk?
Just the same old homesickness. Nothing new.
Tell me about it. I'm always here to lend an ear.
I love being on the sea, and I recognize how important our mission is. But I do wish that I could go back home, sometimes.

Fields.MenuText: Wait, what? That is, I thought...
Ha! That's a good one.
You're a ghost?

Fields.DialogueText: I know it's a dropkick stunt I pulled. I just...
I'm serious, Captain! I've played with you all long enough.
Boo.
It was such a galah stunt that the crew were pulling. And at first it really ate at me.
But once I saw just how silly it all was... well, I couldn't help eating back. Really wrapping my laughing gear around it.
So what you said about shifting from side to side to keep balance...
*ALARM*
Something good?
@BATTLE
Of course, Vampire. What's on your mind?
You will. I can't promise when that might be, but we're going to to everything we can to get you back to the Isle of Wight.
I'm glad you're in my corner, Captain. You're never far away when my mind goes walkabout. I... I can't keep this from you any longer.
Vampire...
It's me. I'm the one behind the haunting.
Can also be used for evil.
No. Hear that? That's evil. You're something else, Vampire.
There's a ghost of a chance.
I'm impressed that you managed to play poltergeist so effectively.

Fields.MenuText: Quite a lot of effort for such a simple prank.
You sure fooled me.
Planning on telling the crew?

Fields.DialogueText: The really elaborate ones look effortless.
I know, and I'm sorry. Where our heads have been at with the ghost stories... I saw an opportunity and couldn't resist.
What would I tell them? Things would just go right back the way they were with me a laughingstock.
This whole time...
Actually, I didn't join in the fun until after we caught those two in the bedsheets that one night.
And was there an endgame?
What do you have in mind, Captain?
I'll tell you once we're through with the Morganas. How strong a swimmer are you?
Oh, a draft here, a flex of an armour plate there... it's the fine control that comes from decades in the field.
Not at first. But just think of why these things scare people, Captain. Unexplained phenomena give rise to all kinds of myths and stories.
After the ghost hunt thing, I thought... well, if there was some kind of benign face on the haunting, the crew might get over their fear and adopt it. Maybe even defeat it.
Get out of their own way.
Well, you raised the ghost. Now we put it to rest.
A taste for the supernatural is as much a muscle as discipline or confidence.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Why me, Captain?
Because you chose me.
No, not that. I mean why should I be the one performing this thing?
You remember that lookout who thought you were a vampire, don't you?
I think we can do everyone one better. Ever perform an exorcism?
You're not seriously suggesting we-
A bit of dinner theatre, eh?
Set a supernatural creature to catch one. It might be nice for the crew to know there's one on their side.
Even a vampire?
Especially a vampire.
Never thought I'd lean into that, but it might be a devil of a good time.
I've been tempted to hide round corners from him and give him a proper scare.
Upgrade from bedsheets and spooky noises? I certainly am. We can time it with the cookout.

Fields.MenuText: Not only that, but you get to throw me to the sharks.

Fields.DialogueText: The ultimate expression of trust.

Fields.MenuText: Maybe this will make our crew a little less superstitious.

Fields.DialogueText: Or more, but in an altogether healthier way.

Fields.MenuText: If the food's as good as I think it'll be, absolutely.

Fields.DialogueText: Let me know how you like your steak, Captain. I like mine bloody!
It shouldn't be hard for me to play the part of a ghost with unfinished business.
Have you some following you around?
*ALARM*
It's on my to-do list.
@BATTLE
Got everything together?
All the fishing line and weights are in place. We just have to make sure the whole setup survives today's Morganas.
Never you fear, Captain. Vampires are real aces at dodging.
Imagine if you could turn to mist.
A girl can dream!
@BATTLE
Oh, this is delicious! You really seasoned this to perfection.
Ha! I was sure you were joking when you said you liked garlic.
Oh, my love for it's deadset, make no mistake.
Shame our ghost couldn't attend, eh?
Wait... do you hear that?

Fields.MenuText: [VENGEFUL MOAN]
[LOUD WHISPERS]
[CLATTERING BONES]

Fields.DialogueText: Looks like we've a crasher, friendos!
Don't listen to its lies!
Noisy blighter, isn't it?
Look there! It's the ghost!
Not to worry. It's walked right into our trap. Notice the salt circle?
Now with a well-placed vial of holy water...
*CREAK*
*SPLASH*
You sent it flying!
Too right! Now to make sure it's gone...
How'd I do?
Caught you! Good thing we're anchored or I might have left you behind!
You're a natural ghost, Captain. Where'd you learn those sounds?
I credit a healthy diet of ghost stories around the campfire when I was younger.
Took a real spirit to make them come in handy, didn't it?
You're amazing, all right. Help me dry off before I become a ghost myself.
I hope you don't mind me watching your exercises.
Not at all, Captain. I never pass up an opportunity to inspire you.
I'm seeing some serious improvement from the crew. They almost caught up to you during that last session.
I think everyone's chuffed after that little display over the barbie.

Fields.MenuText: That might be your plantains at work.
You were a convincing exorcist.
The thing you rigged to throw me into the sea... sure you don't have circus blood?

Fields.DialogueText: I told you I'd cure them of that superstition! They're too sweet to be cursed.
If you look like you know what you're doing, that counts for a lot. Belief is like that.
Oh, you pick up heaps of skills when you've sailed as long as I have. It's fun to dust them off now and again.
Supernatural problems require supernatural solutions.
The ride should be smoother from here on. No more nasty ghosts throwing things, no sir.
There's something on your mind still.
Is there?
You're fidgeting with your skirt. Nervous?
Not at all, Captain. I just...
... Thank you. For sticking along on this madness.
It's important to you, Vampire. That makes it important to me.
Everyone has ghosts and superstitions they like to believe in. It's no different than the myths and legends I like so much.
And it's people that keep them going. Because they mean something. The crew are going to be telling my story for years. I'm... happy you're here to help write it.
I'm happy you chose me to co-author.
Captain...
*ALARM*
The Morganas don't appreciate art, it seems.
They wouldn't know a good story if it blasted them out of the water.
@BATTLE
All right, you tell me about your story first.
Righto. You did win the toss. Very well...
Vampire?
It's... about a ghost, of course. She dies before she can really make her mark on the world. So she spends her afterlife trying to be heard... reaching out to the living any way she can.

Fields.MenuText: Does she succeed?
Is it inspired by... anyone in particular?
That sounds... heartbreaking.

Fields.DialogueText: Eventually. It's just a matter of finding the right person to hear her.
A blend of people and events, like anything.
It is, and for a while she's tempted to give up.
It's a bit of a downer, mostly. To tell you the truth, the writing of it was more interesting to me than the finished product.
Why's that?
There's a lot that goes into a good story - the characters, the plot, the prose. But what's most important to me... is honesty. There's a bit of truth in every one.
Some of what you'll read... some of what it's like to be alone behind a door no one knows is closed...
I swear I heard my sisters whispering it to me from the other side.
Valkyrie and Valhalla?
I don't know why or how. But bloody oath, I'd know their voices anywhere.
Funny you should mention that. My story... oh, you'll laugh.
And if they can live on through my story, why can't I live on through ours?
You think that'll head me off? Come on, spill the goss!
It's about a vampire who falls in love with her prey.
Ooh, that can go all sorts of ways. How does it end?
That's for us to decide.
*ALARM*
Put a bookmark in it?
Reckon! We're at my favourite part.
@BATTLE
Come on, Vampire! You'll miss the war!
Ha! There's no war without me and you know it!
Battle's over. After action reports are done. Nothing to do now but settle in and watch the storm.
You think we'll see more of those santilmo things?

Fields.MenuText: Ball lightning? What causes it, anyway?
Maybe. We might even catch one.
They don't scare you? You know... fire... vampires...

Fields.DialogueText: The jury's still out on that one, Captain. Until they reconvene, it's fun to come up with explanations.
And me without my consecrated butterfly net.
You absolute mug! They wouldn't be nearly hot enough to set me ablaze. We're made of sterner stuff here in the twentieth century.
What did the lookout say was supposed to summon them?
Fresh blood. I think there's more to it than that, though.
How the blood's meant to be spilled?
They say that the santilmo appears after a bloody ruck. Like when two tribes fighting over land have it out.
@BATTLE
So what do they do?
Pick up where the living left off, I hear.
Seems like a miserable afterlife.
Too right. Are they out for revenge? Do they just want to move on?
We might never know.
We might not. But I hope people never stop asking. It might help someone someday.
Oh, bugger! I'd just poured that.
Here, let me help you with that spill... whoa! Vampire, did you see that?
What?
Ball lightning. You missed it when you spilled the... uh...
Shame. Well, there will be others.
Are you all right, Captain? You look like you've seen a ghost.
Maybe I did.
Never you fear, Captain. I know a thing or two about those.
